column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=6. Conclusions
#Text=Flexible operation of DH systems entails significant variations in parameters of DH transmission systems .
#Text=Defining optimal parameters for the transmission system is the key to maintain sufficient heat quality and minimal operation costs .
#Text=Even in a relatively small DH system , precise modelling of each individual component can become crucial as the optimization problem includes such models as constraints .
#Text=Precise modelling of PHX is the most critical for the operation of a transmission system .

#Text=The better the model fits the reality , the less control effort is required at the heat transfer station afterwards and , therefore , secondary temperature deviations from setpoints will be minimal , especially when demand is unpredictable and flexibility is provided ( altering of setpoints ) .
#Text=This also means that the primary return temperature and mass flow will be more predictable .
#Text=Poorly performing models can cause frequent control actions , which result in oscillations in the system , as was seen from the experimental part of this work .
#Text=Both mass flows and temperatures affect heat transfer capability of plate heat exchangers .
#Text=Thus , at various demands plate heat exchangers will produce different return temperatures , which in its turn affects the efficiency of a power-to-heat source ( e. g. , the heat pump ) .

#Text=Especially , this has a greater effect when mass flows and temperatures vary across a wide range , and PHXs , as well as their respective distribution systems , differ significantly in their design ( for instance , rating ) and demand patterns .
#Text=Analysis of heat transfer through DH PHXs has shown that the temperature dependent component of FCC for water has nearly linear behaviour .

#Text=This persists for the whole range of possible temperatures and covers most of the design correlations , as well as for a large range of pressure since it does not affect thermophysical properties of DH water .
#Text=This behaviour allows approximating it as a linear function of temperature where and are fixed and defined by the design , which was validated experimentally on a laboratory PHX .

#Text=The described linear approximation eliminates the use of lookup tables for thermophysical properties for the calculation of OHTC and , therefore , removes the iterative process from the optimization problem .
#Text=The approximation use is not limited to district heating only and can be applied whenever the temperature dependent component of FCC for a fluid exhibits linear behaviour .

#Text=Correlation estimation procedures , outlined in the experimental part of the work , enables finding the most suitable correlation for a particular PHX from temperature and mass flow measurements .
#Text=This can be used in practice when inspection of a PHX model is performed .
#Text=It shows that the correlation accuracy can be further improved by relating its coefficient to one ( or several ) of the varying parameters .

#Text=The two operational optimization study cases show that variable correlation models with linearized temperature dependence perform generally better than the original fixed-temperature thermophysical models , having the same computation time and higher accuracy .
#Text=The proposed models require at least a two-times lower computation time than variable temperature thermophysical models , while having the same accuracy .
#Text=The choice between the models described is made depending on their performance for a specific system and engineering judgement .
#Text=These , due to some models , are not being consistently good at all heat demands .

#Text=In real systems , however , with dozens of heat exchangers and multiple power-to-heat sources , the optimization ( non-linear control ) problem would result in a large number of simulations if all constraints must be satisfied within one optimization interval ( time step ) .
#Text=Besides , the delays in a DH transmission system can reach a dozen of hours , therefore yielding an enormous number of optimization time steps within the given time horizon .
#Text=Thus , computational performance is critical .
#Text=Detailed modelling and control of power to heat sources , i. e. , the coupling units between the sectors , is of high interest , which will be the focus of future work .
